author: Evan Bartlett For Metro.Co.Uk
title: Mark Clattenburg given worst EPL game after Saudi Arabia announcement | Metro News
text:
Evan Bartlett for Metro.co.uk Monday 20 Feb 2017 5:31 pm Clattenburg had been expected to make the move immediately (Getty Images) 
Mark Clattenburg will officiate probably the worst Premier League match available next weekend after announcing that he will soon be leaving England in favour of Saudi Arabia. 
It was expected the referee’s exit would be immediate, but the Premier League raised eyebrows on Monday when it announced its officiating line-up for the weekend and included his name. 
Clattenburg will take charge of the non-televised mid-table clash between West Brom and Bournemouth. Theo Walcott left red-faced as Arsenal fans slam club for 'disrespectful' gesture 
Neither side has any hope of European qualification this season and faces little threat of a relegation scrap. 
The 41-year-old is considered one of the best referees in the world – having officiated the Euro 2016 final, last season’s Champions League final and the FA Cup final. There’s hardly anything riding on West Brom vs Bournemouth (Getty Images) 
But he revealed last week that he is off to become the new head of referees in Saudi Arabia. 
It is believed he had grown increasingly frustrated over a perceived lack of support from the Premier League’s refereeing body Professional Game Match Officials Limited (PGMOL). Next weekend's Premier League fixtures 
Saturday 
Crystal Palace v Middlesbrough (15:00) 
Everton v Sunderland (15:00) 
West Brom v Bournemouth (15:00) 
Watford v West Ham (17:30) 
Sunday 
Tottenham v Stoke City (13:30) 
Monday 
Leicester City v Liverpool (20:00) 
In a press conference in the Middle Eastern kingdom last week, Clattenburg said: ‘This is an important move forward. We have professional referees in the country that I am leaving, which has been a big positive. 
‘One thing I’d like to do is work with the refereeing team and the president to make this happen so that it will be successful for many, many years to come.’
